A large part of my forecast, although taking into account some of the evidence submitted in support of either side, comes down to the fact that SCOTUS chose to hear this case. Since the case only involves private actors, in a scenario that previously led SCOTUS to dismiss suits on the basis of lack of jurisdiction, the decision to hear the case seems to indicate that SCOTUS may be looking to change the interpretation of the ATS made by the 2nd Circuit: namely that, regardless of any other factors or connection to the US, the ATS categorically doesn't allow for corporate liability to be pursued. As such, this case isn't necessarily over jurisdiction (which both the US gov. and previous rulings of SCOTUS seem to indicate is not there) but specifically over whether corporations can be held liable under ATS in the same way individuals can ("Whether the Alien Tort Statute, 28 U.S.C. § 1350,
categorically forecloses corporate liability."). This specific issue, the liability of corporations under ATS, has been brought up before and wasn't resolved then so it seems that SCOTUS may have finally resolved to clarify this point of law (which I think it is going to do in favour of corporations being liable since that was the opposite of the ruling being appealed , but I'm not certain enough to warrant more than 3/4).

The Supreme Court will determine that whether a corporation can be sued under the ATS is a jurisdictional question determined by domestic law and not a substantive question determined by the law of nations.  The exclusion of corporations from liability is, in effect, a case of the law of nations saying that national courts have no jurisdiction to hold corporations liable, and this is a matter over which domestic law should hold sway.  There is no other basis for distinguishing between corporations and other persons in their responsibility for tortious conduct.

Simply put, international lae is not settled on the issue — i.e. there is no readily discernible customary norm. None of the conservative justices, or even liberals (except Breyer) will make a pronouncement on unsettled international law.

Note that if they decide against the plaintiffs or remand without reaching the corporate liability question, it would be a "No" to this question. So that's all in the "No" column. As we all know, SCOTUS often makes landmark decisions that are political but usually it has to cloak its politics behind legal jargon. In this case, however, foreign policy considerations will be taken into account as a matter of law. As discussed in oral argument, someone will frown upon the US no matter which way this case goes. From the point of view of future cases as well as the case at hand, though, it would seem that deciding for the plaintiffs would bring greater difficulties upon the US than dismissing the case and perhaps angering Israel this time around. But it seemed to me Kagan was rather grasping for straws during oral argument when she was conjuring the supposedly dire consequences of denying corporate liability under international law.

After reading the Oral Argument again, and the following analysis from scotusbog.com
http://www.scotusblog.com/2017/10/argument-analysis-corporate-liability-violations-international-law-shaky-ground/
I have to revise down the chance. Justice Kennedy asked only few questions to Mr. Fischer (Jesner side) and Mr. Fischer felt that was important enough (i.e. that Justice Kennedy was not on his side) to first address Justice Kennedy's question (that by ruling for the plaintiff, the Court would dictate a new norm to corporations, especially foreign corporations, on how to behave). Earlier, I misread the exchange and thought Justice Kennedy would remand (send back to lower court) with instruction that it has to consider other issues, such as the question of extraterritorial nexus. Justice Kagan tried to persuade Justice Kennedy to do that, to leave the door open to sue corporations.

Allowing aliens to sue corporations under the ATS would be opening a massive can of worms that the SCOTUS would be loathe to do. My interpretation is that there are two key questions at stake: first, does financing terrorism qualify as violating international law, and second, can corporations be sued for foreign activities if they violate international law.  Roberts, Alito, and Gorsuch appear firmly against the ruling. Sotomayor, Kagan, and Breyer seem to support the plaintiffs. I imagine Thomas and Ginsburg will vote on opposite sides, leaving Kennedy as the swing vote. Which issue Kennedy focuses on will affect the final decision. If he focuses on the first, then I suspect he will vote no since he does not seem to wish to allow international norms to determine US policies. However, if he weighs on the second issue, that corporations can be sued just like individuals in the US for crimes conducted in foreign territory (e.g. independent military contractors committing crimes in war zones), he may swing yes. Justice Kagan's hypothetical example of a US corporation supporting slavery in a foreign country might be enough to persuade Kennedy to preserve this option for the future. http://www.scotusblog.com/2017/10/argument-analysis-corporate-liability-violations-international-law-shaky-ground/

Chap 6 of Justice Stephan Breyer's book "The Court and the World" talks a lot about the alien tort statue.  It was enacted in 1789 and the district courts have original jurisdiction.  It is for torts in violation of THE LAW OF NATIONS or A TREATY OF THE UNITED STATES. It provides foreign citizens with a right of action in American courts so that the could sue for violations of the law of nations.  I would think the financing terrorism falls under a violation of the law of nations. The 9th circuit(date unknown at this time) allowed that a defendant corporation violates the ATS by providing "knowing, practical assistance or encouragement that has a substatantial effect on the perpetration of the crime"  A good reference "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Tort_Statute"

The Court in recent year has been relatively business friendly (e.g. Citizens United). Arab Bank however is based in the Jordan. Expanding the ability to sue corporations is already somewhat unlikely/difficult. The question more particularly, whether the bank can be sued in U.S. courts (in this case, not by U.S. citizens, but by aliens). The Supreme Court ruled before in Kiobel v. Royal Dutch Petroleum that in the same way that U.S. law does not apply outside the U.S., the ATS could not be used to judge corporate liability in the first place, if the activity in question occurred outside of the U.S. [1]. Plaintiff is saying that there is no limitation on who can be a defendant under ATS, and brings back question of corporate liability to be answered. I can't see the court taking a very strong view on the ATS having jurisdiction on something that would be more under the realm of international law. Despite American politicians putting in briefs supporting the plaintiff, wanting concrete power to use “against financial entities that use U.S. operations to aid terrorist attacks on foreign nationals overseas.” [2], I'm not sure it will happen. My usual caveat of me not being a law expert applies. [1, 2] http://www.scotusblog.com/2017/07/introduction-alien-tort-statute-corporate-liability-plain-english/

The question presented in the case is complex and intermingles, United States law, and International Law. A proficient analysis of this case maybe beyond the scope of my education level, at present. Therefore when making my prediction I merely considered whether or not this case met the standard set forth in the statue that dictates if a party has standing. 
That standard is as follows;
"Suits can be brought against corporations for involvement in human rights violations abroad, so long as the corporation had sufficient contacts with the U.S., acted together with a government entity or official and had sufficient control over the violations".
First it's known the bank has enough contact with the USA to meet that component of the requirement . Secondly we know it worked with the Palestinian Authority as well as the  Israeli government,therefore it worked with a government entity meeting  the second component of the standard. And in considering the third component it would be logical to assume that the banks board of directors could surmise the purpose of the monies that it funneled to and from known terrorists.However the banks knowledge that it was a conduit for terrorist activities, isn't indicative that it had any control over the terrorist acts/human rigths violations.  Given the criteria  It doesn't meet the standard .

As a preamble, I am making this statement under the assumption that Arab Bank, PLC is not a bank chartered in the United States. I would assume it's a Great Britain bank, based upon the "Publicly Limited Company" designation in its name. If it is a bank with operations in the United States, then what follows is moot. No United States court has proper jurisdiction to even hear this case, since the bank is not chartered in the United States. There is no proper reason for a case as this to ever be heard in the United States for that reason. If the plaintiffs should be entitled to sue, they should only be entitled to sue where the bank operates and is chartered to operate. The boundaries of United States law should not apply beyond this nation's borders. For the court to decide otherwise should require a declaration of war by Congress. Right now, the United States is fighting with Switzerland and bankers located there about their banks accepting business from United States citizens. While I feel that it is completely illegal for the United States to forbid any of its citizens from doing business with anyone else, the United States seems to be winning that war already. It is wrong, and I hope the Supreme Court recognizes that this is a case of the same cloth, and should be suppressed.

Hairs will be split in this decision, so I am staying near the cowardly middle for a while.

The wild card in this case would appear to be the position that the Advocate takes in arguing the case. I am not currently clear what the position of the State Department and the Administration is on this. One one hand there seems to be a push toward a free-enterprise international market. On the other hand, the Administration wishes to renegotiate historical practices, treaties, and so on. This is a tossup.
